nodes.text: Reporting both the ensemble-average (GDP per capita) growth rate and the time-average (DDP per capita) growth rate, and their difference, yields a more complete and policy-relevant picture of national economic performance than reporting GDP per capita growth alone
Under random multiplicative income dynamics (Gibrat type models) incomes evolve by successive proportional multiplicative shocks and the ergodicity transformation is the logarithm of income
The ensemble-average growth rate is the growth rate of the population mean income (GDP per capita) and is approximately an income-weighted (plutocratic) average of individual growth rates

The time-average growth rate equals the long-time growth experienced by an individual and is the growth rate of the geometric mean income (DDP per capita), i.e. an equally weighted (democratic) average of individual growth rates

The difference between ensemble-average and time-average growth rates defines a natural inequality measure, the ergodicity gap J(t) = ln(mean income) - mean(ln income), equal to the mean logarithmic deviation (MLD) or Theil index two

Policy implication: if GDP per capita grows faster than DDP per capita citizens may experience stagnating or lower long-run typical growth leading to political disconnect; statistical authorities should report GDP per capita growth, DDP per capita growth, and the ergodicity gap
Mathematical result: after log transformation the additive growth rate g = delta ln x / delta t is ergodic, so ensemble and time averages of g coincide in the model

Analytic example (geometric Brownian motion): ensemble-average growth rate g_mean = mu, time-average growth rate g_time = mu - sigma squared over two, so ensemble-average exceeds time-average by sigma squared over two

Practical estimation claim: the time-average growth rate and the ergodicity gap depend only on initial and terminal income distributions (geometric mean and mean of log incomes) and thus can be estimated from cross-sectional or quantile data without panel data or mobility information

Model implication: under pure multiplicative random growth (GBM) the ergodicity gap (MLD) grows linearly over time (J(t) = sigma squared times t over two) and inequality increases without bound absent other mechanisms

Method used on data: compute ensemble-average growth from mean income series, compute time-average growth from changes in geometric mean estimated using quantile averages and truncation safeguards for low incomes

Empirical evidence: United States 1966-2014 shows divergence since 1980 with GDP per capita growth exceeding DDP per capita growth (ensemble +40% vs time +20%), while France shows much closer ensemble and time growth rates over the last fifty years
Empirical evidence: the ergodicity gap evolution correlates strongly with top 10% income share (correlation 0.94 US, 0.79 France) indicating the ergodicity gap tracks standard inequality measures
Assumption: income dynamics are reasonably approximated by random multiplicative processes for the theoretical comparisons and analytic results to apply

Limitation: pure multiplicative models ignore redistribution, interactions, and institutional reallocation mechanisms which can reduce divergence; empirical deviations (e.g. France) indicate those mechanisms matter
